node.title: PorousFlow sinks
node.bodyText:
I'm sorry for bringing another simple question...
I'm modeling Theis problem but instead of PorousFlowSquarePulsePointSource I would like to use PorousFlowSink. However, for some reason nothing happens:
[Mesh]
type = GeneratedMesh
dim = 2
nx = 20
ny = 1
ymax = 1
xmax = 100
bias_x = 1.05
[]
[Problem]
coord_type = RZ
[]
[GlobalParams]
PorousFlowDictator = dictator
[]
[Variables]
[pp]
initial_condition = 20E6
[]
[]
[PorousFlowBasicTHM]
dictator_name = dictator
add_darcy_aux = false
fp = simple_fluid
gravity = '0 0 0'
multiply_by_density = false
porepressure = pp
[]
[Modules]
[FluidProperties]
[simple_fluid]
type = SimpleFluidProperties
viscosity = 0.001
[]
[]
[]
[Materials]
[porosity]
type = PorousFlowPorosityConst
porosity = 0.05
[]
[biot_mod]
type = PorousFlowConstantBiotModulus
fluid_bulk_modulus = 2E9
biot_coefficient = 1.0
[]
[permeability]
type = PorousFlowPermeabilityConst
permeability = '1E-14 0 0 0 1E-14 0 0 0 1E-14'
[]
[]
[BCs]
[sink]
type = PorousFlowSink
variable = pp
flux_function = 0.16E-3
boundary = left
[]
[]
[VectorPostprocessors]
[pp]
type = LineValueSampler
num_points = 25
start_point = '0 0 0'
end_point = '100 0 0'
sort_by = x
variable = pp
[]
[]
[Preconditioning]
[smp]
type = SMP
full = true
[]
[]
[Executioner]
type = Transient
solve_type = Newton
dt = 200
end_time = 1E3
nl_abs_tol = 1e-10
[]
[Outputs]
[csv]
type = CSV
execute_on = final
[]
[]
Also, how is the area of the sink defined in this case? Would it be 2 * pi * Radius * height?
Thanks MOOSE
Matias

Hi Matias,
It is most likely due to the zero surface area for the sink at r = 0. Shift the mesh slightly (eg xmin = 0.1 in the Mesh block) and it should work (injection is through the area of the cylinder like you had above). You can use an AreaPostProcessor to compute the surface area of the sink for you and compute the flux for your sink in a function.
There is an example of this in https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/06bc1f73f0d4dfb3d01ce9ba77d6bb97346e07eb/modules/porous_flow/examples/restart/gas_injection.i
Thanks @cpgr! This solve my question.

node.title: Newbie to MOOSE
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
I am a newbie to moose. I have installed moose software on Ubuntu 20.04. Now I don't know how to use the software. Is there any written guidelines or user manual on how to use this software? My goal is to do a fracture/fail mechanism (crystal plasticity) on a metal (Ti64) microstructure.
Thank you
Karthi
I suggest look at https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/examples_and_tutorials/index.html

Hi Andy,
Thanks so much.
karthi

Hello Karthi,
I think this will help more than the documentation, but that's just my opinion.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=V7azGBtIkQA&list=PLct8iNZXls-CqvXrFk68E5QwPwsnMmyYo
Cheers :)

node.title: Discontinuous Galerkin Advection in 3D
node.bodyText:
Has anybody developed code and examples to use Discontinuous Galerkin in 3D, for instance to model advection?
I was looking at the test case here:
https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/modules/rdg/test/tests/advection_1d/1d_aefv_square_wave.i
My understanding is that if I need to implement the same model in 3D model,
I will need to:

Extend AEFVSlopeLimitingOneD to calculate gradients in 3D
Extend AEFVUpwindInternalSideFlux to use a 3D velocity vector

while the AEFVKernel seems to be already suitable for 3D,
and same for AEFVMaterial.
Am I right?
Could you give me some hints about the implementation?
Thank you very much in advance for your suggestions,
Best Regards,
Nicolò

Disclaimer, I'm fairly new to MOOSE and am still learning but I think the examples you're looking at are more about using DG to implement a Finite Volume method (more natural FV capabilities are in the works) and less about using DG to solve the problem. In the tests directory you'll find a lot more examples with DG (for example 3D DG examples). Checkout test/tests/dgkernels, I haven't looked at them in depth but just glancing I'm seeing 3d_diffusion, ad_dg_convection, advection_diffusion_mixed_bcs.

Dear @jbadger95
Thank you very much for pointing me to those files.
Now I see DGKernels are also implemented in the framework and not only in the rdg module.
I will try them. Thank you again.
Best Regards,
Nicolò

Dear MOOSE users,
following up my initial question:
now I learned how to use the DG kernel for advection.
Now I would like to do coupled advection, I mean I want to implement the equation:

where u is my variable, rho is a coupled variable and v the velocity.
The question is: how should I modify the DGConvection kernel?
The main challenge is that I need to get the coupled variable in the neighbouring element,
so, for instance in the residual calculation, I will have a variable _rho_coupled_neighbor
instead of the variable _u_neighbor
while I think the variable _u[_qp] can be simply substituted by _rho_coupled[_qp] which is obtained by:
_rho_coupled(coupledValue("rho_coupled")), this is the easy part I think.
I saw in the base class DGKernel that the variable in the neighbour element is obtained by:
_u_neighbor(_is_implicit ? _var.slnNeighbor() : _var.slnOldNeighbor()),
However: _var(*mooseVariable()) gets the variable on which the kernel is applied, so u.
So, the question is: is there a function similar to mooseVariable() which can provide me a coupled variable instead, given its name?
Any other suggestion to reach my goal?
DGCoupledDiffusion.C under moose/test/src/dgkernels shows us how to couple variables in DG kernels.

It is not using more strait-forward functions provided in NeighborCoupleable. Maybe MOOSE developers can comment on this? I was expecting to see something like
    _v(coupledValue("v")),
    _v_neighbor(coupledNeighborValue("v")),

You can try this to see if it works or not.

Dear MOOSE users,
following up my initial question:
now I have implemented the DG kernel for coupled advection:
https://github.com/ngrilli/c_pfor_am/blob/main/src/dgkernels/DGAdvectionCoupledVConst.C
The equations I am trying to solve are:

$\rho_e$ and $\rho_t$ are the two variables.
v is a constant velocity (v = 1.0) along positive x axis.
An initial vertical strip contains the non-zero phase field and I want to see the advection towards the right.
I think the implementation is correct because I see the correct solution at up to time t = 1.0 when the variable reaches at the boundary,
see image below:

I think the advection s correct, but there are two things:

Periodic BC do not work, the field clearly does not transfer from right to left
After a certain time, when the field is at the boundary, I see $\rho_e$ and $\rho_t$ get very large value and simulation diverge.

Point 2) I really don't understand because there is nothing in the equations themselves that can give this divergence.
I tried with different shape functions (MONOMIAL, L2_LAGRANGE)
and with/without periodic BC, Dirichlet BC also give the same effect.
Any suggestion is very much appreciated.
The input file is copied in the following, and also available here:
https://github.com/ngrilli/c_pfor_am/blob/main/test/tests/DGKernels/DGtestVConst.i
Best Regards,
Nicolò
[Mesh]

  [./gen]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    dim = 3
    nx = 10
    ny = 10
    nz = 1
    xmax = 2.0
    ymax = 2.0
    zmax = 0.2
    elem_type = HEX8
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'  
  [../] 

[]

[GlobalParams]

[]

[Variables]
 
  [./rho_t]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
    [./InitialCondition]
      type = FunctionIC
      function = init_rho_t
    [../]
  [../]
  
  [./rho_gnd_edge]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
    [./InitialCondition]
      type = FunctionIC
      function = init_rho_gnd_edge
    [../]
  [../]
  
[]

[AuxVariables]

[]

[Functions]

  [./dts]
    type = PiecewiseConstant
    x = '0.0 10.0'
    y = '0.1 0.1'
  [../]
  
  [./init_rho_gnd_edge]
    type = ParsedFunction
	value = 'if(3.0*(x-1.0),0.0,1.0)'
  [../]
  
  [./init_rho_t]
    type = ParsedFunction
	value = 'if(3.0*(x-1.0),0.0,1.0)'
  [../]
  
[]

[UserObjects]

[]

[Kernels]

  [./drho_gnd_edge_dt]
    type = TimeDerivative
    variable = rho_gnd_edge
  [../]

  [./drho_t_dt]
    type = TimeDerivative
    variable = rho_t
  [../]  
    
[]

[DGKernels]

  [./rho_t_advection_edge]
    type = DGAdvectionCoupledVConst
    variable = rho_gnd_edge
	rho_coupled = rho_t
    velocity = '1 0 0'
  [../] 
  
  [./rho_gnd_edge_advection]
    type = DGAdvectionCoupledVConst
    variable = rho_t
	rho_coupled = rho_gnd_edge
    velocity = '1 0 0'
  [../]

[]

[AuxKernels]

[]

[BCs]
  
  [./Periodic]
  
    [./auto_rho_t_boundary_x]
      variable = rho_t
      primary = 'left'
	  secondary = 'right'
	  translation = '2.0 0.0 0.0'
    [../]
    [./auto_rho_gnd_edge_boundary_x]
      variable = rho_gnd_edge
      primary = 'left'
	  secondary = 'right'
      translation = '2.0 0.0 0.0'  
    [../]
	
    [./auto_rho_t_boundary_y]
      variable = rho_t
      primary = 'bottom'
	  secondary = 'top'
	  translation = '0.0 2.0 0.0'
    [../]
    [./auto_rho_gnd_edge_boundary_y]
      variable = rho_gnd_edge
      primary = 'bottom'
	  secondary = 'top'
      translation = '0.0 2.0 0.0'	  
    [../]
	
    [./auto_rho_t_boundary_z]
      variable = rho_t
      primary = 'back'
	  secondary = 'front'
	  translation = '0.0 0.0 0.2'
    [../]
    [./auto_rho_gnd_edge_boundary_z]
      variable = rho_gnd_edge
      primary = 'back'
	  secondary = 'front'
	  translation = '0.0 0.0 0.2'
    [../]

  [../]  
  
[]
 
[Postprocessors]

[]

[Materials]

[]

[Preconditioning]
  
  active = 'smp'
  
  [./smp]
    type = SMP
    full = true
  [../]
  
[]

[Executioner]

  type = Transient
  solve_type = 'PJFNK'
  petsc_options = '-snes_ksp_ew'
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_factor_mat_solver_package'
  petsc_options_value = 'lu superlu_dist'
  
  line_search = 'none'
  automatic_scaling = true
  
  l_max_its = 50
  nl_max_its = 50
  nl_rel_tol = 1e-8
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-10
  
  [./TimeStepper]
    type = FunctionDTGrowth
    function = dts
	cutback_factor_at_failure = 0.1
	growth_factor = 1.2
  [../]

  start_time = 0.0
  end_time = 10.0
  
  dtmin = 1.0e-10
  timestep_tolerance = 1.0e-10
[]

[Outputs]

  csv = false

  [./out]
    type = Exodus
    interval = 1
  [../]
  
[]

Dear @GiudGiud
Apologies but I am not sure what you mean by reflective BC.
Could you point me to an example in moose?
I only tried removing all BC, so it should be zero flux and I get the same solution as with periodic.
I also tried dirichlet and penalty dirichlet but I get the same problem of the high value of the variable and oscillations appearing
at the boundary after some time.
I don't specifically need periodic BC, but I was just trying to setup a simulation
that can work even if there are accumulation of the variable at the boundaries.
Otherwise, is there any other way to make conservative advection with a coupled variable in moose?
I made this code some time ago:
https://github.com/ngrilli/c_pfor_am/blob/main/src/kernels/ConservativeAdvectionCoupled.C
but it was not working well, I am not enough familiar with the framework to modify properly
the function fullUpwind(JacRes res_or_jac)
in such a way that it can work with a coupled variable.
This code was taken from:
https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/framework/src/kernels/ConservativeAdvection.C
but my modifications of fullUpwind(JacRes res_or_jac) were probably not correct.
If someone can help with this, it would be great.
Nicolò

Reflective should be the zero flux here.
The other way, and probably the best way, to do conservative advection is to use finite volume. You can have a look at the advection kernels for incompressible navier stokes. For advection with a constant velocity there's a simple one in the framework, FVAdvection.
For advection with a coupled variable velocity, INSFVMomentum/MassAdvection are more useful.
Note that DG should work too, Im just less familiar with it so cant really help
Guillaume

Sorry, I did not notice this. You seem missing a kernel for the convection term. Check this moose/test/tests//dgkernels/1d_advection_dg/1d_advection_dg.i out. We apply integration by parts for the convection term multiplied with a test function resulting into a normal kernel and a dg kernel.

Dear @YaqiWang
Thank you, really, your comment was illuminating for me.
So let me see if I understand well:

The DG kernels are taking care of the discontinuity of the shape functions at the elements boundaries.
The normal kernels are taking care of the bulk term, where shape functions can have a gradient, which must be considered for advection.
Therefore, I need to use both at the same time.
Does this make sense?

I have implemented both normal kernel for coupled advection and DG kernel for coupled advection and I am using them together.
The result is correct now, see the following picture compared to the one I posted above:

I can see that the advection is definitely conservative and there is no more solution divergence when the
field remains blocked at the boundary like before.
Main features:

I am able to run these simulations with both first order monomial and constant monomial variables
periodic BC do not do anything in both cases, but that was the same as I found earlier, not very important for my project anyway
the key to avoid the divergence at the end is actually to add the line "implicit = false" in all the advection kernels,
as it is done in the example in moose:
https://github.com/idaholab/moose/tree/next/test/tests/dgkernels/1d_advection_dg
If I don't use "implicit = false", I have the divergence problem discussed above even with the combined DG + non-DG kernels.

Anyway the solution looks much more correct now and I will pursue further this method for my problem.
If anyone is interested, my kernels for coupled advection and test cases are here:
https://github.com/ngrilli/c_pfor_am/blob/main/test/tests/DGKernels/DGtestConstMonomial.i
https://github.com/ngrilli/c_pfor_am/blob/main/src/dgkernels/DGAdvectionCoupledVConst.C
https://github.com/ngrilli/c_pfor_am/blob/main/src/kernels/AdvectionCoupledVConst.C
Thank you very much again,
Nicolò

Glad it is working. I am not so sure about this implicit = false. This is making the kernel coupling the variable of the previous time step. I would think it should work without this implicit. You may want to double check.

node.title: I cannot compile application suddenly
node.bodyText:
Until yesterday noon, I can recompile my application whenever I want.
But, suddenly with this error message, I cannot recompile the application anymore.

I tried to set MOOSE_DIR, first.
(MOOSE_DIR=/anaconda3/envs/moose/ or MOOSE_DIR=/Users/HOKON/projects/moose)
Both of MOOSE_DIR doesn't give me change for fixing the problem, so I unset the MOOSE_DIR currently.
What am I supposed to do fix this problem?
I always appreciate help for MOOSE!
============================================
I searched trobuleshooting in the MOOSE website.
I did "conda update -all" and "make -j4" in my application folder.

Now, I got above error.... I am stuck... I think I should wait for a reply from MOOSE staff...
============================================
PS. Because I work on two kinds of operating system (Windows 10 on desktop and MacOS on laptop),
   Usually I edited the source kernel (*.c and *.h) on Windows 10(desktop).

   After that, I copy and paste the edited source kernel to application "src" and "include" folders existed at MacOs(laptop).

   Can this kind of copying and pasting the source codes cause the issue like this?

   I knew the file type? is different between Windows 10(NTFS) and MacOS(..?).

   Even the file format is the same, working different OS for the source code might be an issue for this??

Hello
Issue with loading dynamic libraries are commonly due to having an old build lying around. We recommend using make clobberall to clean up the directory, then compiing again.
If that doesn't work, it may be that the cleaning was not enough. In which case, you should commit ALL your chances, then run git clean -xfd.
This type of copy pasting should be fine. You could get issues with line endings if you moved the file, but copy pasting probably works.
I would recommend using a shared folder for doing this though, or just coding on the mac, for a more efficient workflow.
Guillaume

I think now an issue to laptop looks solved.
I tried to recompile the application on HPC.
After "make clobberall" and "make -j4" in my application directory.


If I recompile without module (this means, Iuse the local MOOSE in my account),
it works properly, only for a one time. After the modification of src and include folders, I cannot recompile again.
What I saw was the same message Iike above.
"Using HIT from..." and back to command line. It doesn't look like compile.


If I recompile the application with the MOOSE module,
I got error messages like below.



I asked this to HPC staff as well, and wait for his reply. But I don't know why this happens.
For your information, I run a simulation on HPC by using this bash file.

Usually, I do not comment out the load module command line.. (2nd one, latest MOOSE)
I knew without loading the MOOSE module, above bash file works.
Let me clear....
"How I fix the compiling problem on HPC in this situation?"
"What is the function of Module on HPC? I thought Module let me use the virtual environment.
I thought If I load "MOOSE module", then even without local MOOSE file,
I could make new application (./moose/scirpts/stork.sh app_name), but actually it doesn't work.
Is there any documents for how module works or what is module on HPC?"
I always appreciate your help!

If you have not modified any files after you compiled, it will not recompile. Because everything is already compiled.
So this may be why you are seeing this "it compiles only once" behavior
Please search the Discussions board for HPC modules related discussions. This has come up recently.
You cannot switch between MPI distributions between moose and your application, this is likely what is happening here given the error message

Also, please refrain from posting pictures of text whenever possible; Search queries cannot find text within a picture (therefor hindering the next user from finding answers if they happen to hit the same error you posted).

node.title: transform_func in 3D?
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I am rotating a regular 3D geometry: does the transform_func approach to setting the periodic boundaries only work in 2D?
I get this error
[31] ./include/libmesh/remote_elem.h, line 120, compiled Feb 16 2021 at 16:53:25

*** ERROR ***
Error: not implemented!

My input file for example contains:
  [./Periodic]
    [./x]
      primary = bottom
      secondary = top
      transform_func = 'tr_x tr_y tr_z'
      inv_transform_func = 'itr_x itr_y itr_z'
    [../]
  [../]

and I see there are only 2D examples in the bcs/periodic tests. Thanks!

Update: top and bottom are for y-faces (not x-)!
"Not implemented" is a bad way of telling me I am wrong
related to libMesh/libmesh#2958

node.title: compile petsc on cluster
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I am trying to install moose on a cluster, and I get the following error when installing petsc:
Trying to download git://https://bitbucket.org/petsc/pkg-mumps.git for MUMPS
Compiling Mumps; this may take several minutes
UNABLE to CONFIGURE with GIVEN OPTIONS    (see configure.log for details):
Error running make on MUMPS
Attached is the configure.log. Also, here are the loaded modules:
Currently Loaded Modules:

shared   2) cpu/0.15.4   3) DefaultModules   4) gcc/10.2.0   5) python/3.8.5   6) slurm/expanse/20.02.3   7) sdsc/1.0   8) cmake/3.18.2   9) openmpi/4.0.4

Thank you very much for your help,
Roozbeh
configure.log

Hi Roozbeh
A few of the first errors are referencing dos.h. This is odd since your cluster should be on linux.
Can you check your environment PATH, CC, CXX, FC, etc for anything odd?
@fdkong who's the expert on mumps?
And do we absolutely need mumps or is it once of the ones we can disable temporarily?
Guillaume

Hi Guillaume,
Thanks for your response. Actually I recompiled today using the module mvapich2, and it worked.
Cheers,
Roozbeh

I am having the same problem with compiling PETSc too, but my error is as follows:
TESTING: checkCCompiler from config.setCompilers(config/BuildSystem/config/setCompilers.py:717)                                                                                                               *******************************************************************************
UNABLE to CONFIGURE with GIVEN OPTIONS    (see configure.log for details):
Could not locate a functional C compiler
Any clue? Thanks
This question has been answered. If the steps which lead to that answer didn't work for you, please start a new discussion.

node.title: Questions about coupled variable and global parameter
node.bodyText:
I made an application that has 3 variables and 3 kernels.
I would like to introduce a new variable and there is no kernel for this variable.
What I want to know is
"Can coupled variable (introduced new variable) be changed by off-diagonal jacobian?"
Also, in this application, I set the global parameter (e.g. A=1000).

Like above, there is a pipe. Everywhere in pipe has constant A (A=1000), except for triangle (A=0).
So far, A was constant number, however I want to change A at a certain condition(place). Is it possible through MOOSE?

Dear @hokonkim
The coupling of a variable inside a user defined kernel is described in example number 3:
https://github.com/idaholab/moose/tree/next/examples/ex03_coupling
If you specify better your equations and the terms you want to introduce, it is easier to help you.
If you want a different A parameter in different part of the geometry the best strategy is to create multiple "blocks",
this can be done in gmsh by specifying more "physical volumes".
"A" can be defined as a material property in a material object, then restrict the material to a certain block,
you will need two materials with A = 0 and A = 1000 in your simulation.
The material property can be imported into the kernel with getMaterialProperty, you can see many examples of this in this repository:
https://github.com/ngrilli/c_pfor_am
Best Regards,
Nicolò

@ngrilli Thanks for your reply.
If the geometry (pipe) consists of one volume (block), then what is the best way to implement this?
You will want to use a function to define the spatial dependency if you want to only use one block

I tried to check "Functions" in Syntax, however still I have no idea about this.
Could you point me out for specific syntax?  or
Is there any uploaded input examples at MOOSE framework website?

Just use a ParsedFunction for the defintion. Then a (AD?) GenericFunctionMaterial to take that parsed function
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/functions/MooseParsedFunction.html
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/materials/GenericFunctionMaterial.html

Dear @hokonkim
If you have no specific reason to use a single block, just add another block.
You need to create two "physical volumes" in gmsh.
There are plenty of examples online, for instance this one:
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/53914425/create-single-mesh-for-multiple-bodies-in-gmsh
Nicolò

I fully agree with Nicolo that this is the more natural way to do this.
Doing a single block is likely not to capture the true shape of that triangle, unless you are very careful with meshing

@ngrilli @GiudGiud
I think it needs more detail explanation.
What I am trying to implement is degradation ("poisoning) happens in the fuel cell.
When degradation happens, somewhere in TPB (in previous discussion, I said the pipe) will be deactivated.
If somewhere in TPB is deactivated, then that point(element?) in TPB should be shut off or at least there is no more reaction contributing to a performance.
Also, in TPB, there is an only S0 constants related to TPB reaction.
In terms of volumetric mesh, TPB is just one mesh.
So, I tried to find a way to give a zero S0 value to deactivated TPB  when TPB are poisoned.

so you're trying to remove elements during the simulation essentially?
or just disable the reaction in those elements?
For the latter:
If you go the function route, you can make that function depend on time.
If you need more fine grained control you will have to create your own reaction kernel, and have the criteria for activation/deactivation of the reaction there.

@GiudGiud
I think disabling the reaction in the elements is enough.
I've made a simple function in an input file.
But, "how to disable the reaction in the element?". Are there any examples I can refer?
I've made several reaction kernels as well, but still I need to think more about this if I want to use kernel...
Can I control a reaction with probability?
ex) when species A and B exist in (or near) an element, A + B -> C reaction occurs with 0.01% probability.
PS. Can GlobalParams in input file override the value given at the source kernel?
ex) (input file) GlobalParams/z = 8
(source kernel) params.addParam("z", 4.0, "Electron number (num of electrons transferred)");
In this case, z = 8 or z = 4?

Ok good, that is very doable. What does the disabling depend on?
If it's just a profile that you are imposing and that you already know the time dependence of, then just use a function in space and time. Then use a reaction kernel with a function for the coefficent.
If not that use a (material property + reaction kernel with coefficient material property) OR (reaction kernel with the coefficient hard-coded in the kernel)  and put in the criteria for disabling here.
Theoretically speaking, you absolutely could use a probabilistic approach. I do not think it is required here, a continuous approach will be just as easy to follow, and will not necessitate an uncertainty study.
GlobalParams can fill the parameters yes.
For example for this parameter you gave, the default of 4 is not used, the global parameter is used.
Now if you specify for that given block a value of 6 in the input block, then BOTH the default and the global parameters are overridden.

node.title: Coupled Properties Update in a MultiApp to Decouple Flow and Mechanics Physics
node.bodyText:
I am building a MultiApp to decouple the poro-elasticity problems. The transfer will be for the non-linear variables between the apps, pressure and displacement which is not possible because the transfer is allowed only for auxVariables.
The fluid flow materApp is structured in a way that the material objects call a porous-media dictator that combines the non-linear variables. It is needed for populating the coupled fluid properties, e.g. density, viscosity,… which are function of nonlinear variables, e.g., pressure. That pressure is updated while the solution proceeds and the dictator’s job is to pass that updated field to these materials’ objects to be reevaluated.
In our workflow, we need to update the fluid-flow coupled properties which depends on the mechanics attributes, e.g. strain, porosity, and pore volume as a result of the updated results from the mechanics app – displacement. I tried to enforce the displacement as auxVariables. As per the following error, the dictator did not allow combining the displacement as auxVariables. So, based on my understanding, we should rewrite that dictator in a way that can facilitate accepting the auxVariables. Another option is to store the mechanics auxVariables (displacements) to fake nonlinear variables which will require a non-needed additional kernels.


I need also to copy the pressure as a non linear variable in an auxVariable so I can pass it to the subApp. Do you have a suggestion for that?
Do you have suggestions for those two points!

@WilkAndy, @cbolisetti and I were trying to help Ahmed with this.  He is going to break the poro_elasticity/mandel.i input up into a multiapp.   The poro-elasticity problem would then be two separate problems, elasticity by itself on the subapp and darcy flow on the main app.  The main app would send pressure to the subapp and the subapp would send displacements back to the main app.  The main app would use the displacement auxvariables received form the subapp as to compute a new porosity.  The main app will probably also need to solve for the other derivatives that are found in PoroFullSatMaterial.C.  I think the subapp receives the pressure and applies it as a body load.
Maybe @AhmedAlmetwally  could comment on the accuracy of what I wrote.
Thanks @lynnmunday! That is correct.

Just saw this while searching the discussions and was curious as I have never done this decoupling of fluid and mechanics. I thought I would give it a quick try on the mandel.i test, and managed to split this test into two: a fluid flow app and mechanics sub app. Apart from the initial few steps where I haven't put in an initial condition, the MultiApp version converges to the fully coupled results.

I can post the input files if you like, but basically I removed the displacements from the PorousFlowDictator in the fluid app, and the porepressure in the mechanics sub app, and used MultiAppCopyTransfers to copy variables to aux variables between the apps.
Thanks for doing this @cpgr .   I failed to see this question, sorry @AhmedAlmetwally and @lynnmunday

Thanks, @cpgr @WilkAndy,
Yes, that was the right approach and I did the same and get a good match.
Would you please share your .i files to compare!
@lynnmunday, FYI!
Regards

Sure - here are the two input files I used:
# Mandel's problem of consolodation of a drained medium - fluid flow master app

[Mesh]
  type = GeneratedMesh
  dim = 3
  nx = 10
  ny = 1
  nz = 1
  xmin = 0
  xmax = 1
  ymin = 0
  ymax = 0.1
  zmin = 0
  zmax = 1
[]

[GlobalParams]
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
  PorousFlowDictator = dictator
  block = 0
[]

[UserObjects]
  [dictator]
    type = PorousFlowDictator
    porous_flow_vars = 'porepressure'
    number_fluid_phases = 1
    number_fluid_components = 1
  []
  [pc]
    type = PorousFlowCapillaryPressureVG
    m = 0.8
    alpha = 1e-5
  []
[]

[Variables]
  [porepressure]
  []
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [disp_x]
  []
  [disp_y]
  []
  [disp_z]
  []
[]

[BCs]
  [xmax_drained]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = porepressure
    value = 0
    boundary = right
  []
[]

[Kernels]
  [poro_vol_exp]
    type = PorousFlowMassVolumetricExpansion
    variable = porepressure
    fluid_component = 0
  []
  [mass0]
    type = PorousFlowMassTimeDerivative
    fluid_component = 0
    variable = porepressure
  []
  [flux]
    type = PorousFlowAdvectiveFlux
    variable = porepressure
    gravity = '0 0 0'
    fluid_component = 0
  []
[]

[Modules]
  [FluidProperties]
    [simple_fluid]
      type = SimpleFluidProperties
      bulk_modulus = 8
      density0 = 1
      thermal_expansion = 0
      viscosity = 1
    []
  []
[]

[Materials]
  [temperature]
    type = PorousFlowTemperature
  []
  [eff_fluid_pressure]
    type = PorousFlowEffectiveFluidPressure
  []
  [vol_strain]
    type = PorousFlowVolumetricStrain
  []
  [ppss]
    type = PorousFlow1PhaseP
    porepressure = porepressure
    capillary_pressure = pc
  []
  [massfrac]
    type = PorousFlowMassFraction
  []
  [simple_fluid]
    type = PorousFlowSingleComponentFluid
    fp = simple_fluid
    phase = 0
  []
  [porosity]
    type = PorousFlowPorosity
    fluid = true
    mechanical = true
    ensure_positive = false
    porosity_zero = 0.1
    biot_coefficient = 0.6
    solid_bulk = 1
  []
  [permeability]
    type = PorousFlowPermeabilityConst
    permeability = '1.5 0 0   0 1.5 0   0 0 1.5'
  []
  [relperm]
    type = PorousFlowRelativePermeabilityCorey
    n = 0 # unimportant in this fully-saturated situation
    phase = 0
  []
[]

[MultiApps]
  [mechanics]
    type = TransientMultiApp
    input_files = mandel_mechanics.i
    execute_on = 'INITIAL TIMESTEP_BEGIN'
  []
[]

[Transfers]
  [porepressure]
    type = MultiAppCopyTransfer
    direction = to_multiapp
    multi_app = mechanics
    source_variable = porepressure
    variable = porepressure
  []
  [disp]
    type = MultiAppCopyTransfer
    direction = from_multiapp
    multi_app = mechanics
    source_variable = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
    variable = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
  []
  [total_force]
    type = MultiAppPostprocessorTransfer
    multi_app = mechanics
    direction = from_multiapp
    reduction_type = average
    from_postprocessor = total_downwards_force
    to_postprocessor = total_downwards_force
  []
[]

[Postprocessors]
  [p0]
    type = PointValue
    outputs = csv
    point = '0.0 0 0'
    variable = porepressure
  []
  [p1]
    type = PointValue
    outputs = csv
    point = '0.1 0 0'
    variable = porepressure
  []
  [p2]
    type = PointValue
    outputs = csv
    point = '0.2 0 0'
    variable = porepressure
  []
  [p3]
    type = PointValue
    outputs = csv
    point = '0.3 0 0'
    variable = porepressure
  []
  [p4]
    type = PointValue
    outputs = csv
    point = '0.4 0 0'
    variable = porepressure
  []
  [p5]
    type = PointValue
    outputs = csv
    point = '0.5 0 0'
    variable = porepressure
  []
  [p6]
    type = PointValue
    outputs = csv
    point = '0.6 0 0'
    variable = porepressure
  []
  [p7]
    type = PointValue
    outputs = csv
    point = '0.7 0 0'
    variable = porepressure
  []
  [p8]
    type = PointValue
    outputs = csv
    point = '0.8 0 0'
    variable = porepressure
  []
  [p9]
    type = PointValue
    outputs = csv
    point = '0.9 0 0'
    variable = porepressure
  []
  [p99]
    type = PointValue
    outputs = csv
    point = '1 0 0'
    variable = porepressure
  []
  [xdisp]
    type = PointValue
    outputs = csv
    point = '1 0.1 0'
    variable = disp_x
  []
  [ydisp]
    type = PointValue
    outputs = csv
    point = '1 0.1 0'
    variable = disp_y
  []
  [total_downwards_force]
     type = Receiver
     outputs = csv
  []
  [dt]
    type = FunctionValuePostprocessor
    outputs = console
    function = if(0.15*t<0.01,0.15*t,0.01)
  []
[]


[Preconditioning]
  [andy]
    type = SMP
    full = true
    petsc_options_iname = '-ksp_type -pc_type -sub_pc_type -snes_atol -snes_rtol -snes_max_it'
    petsc_options_value = 'gmres asm lu 1E-14 1E-10 10000'
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  solve_type = Newton
  start_time = 0
  end_time = 0.7
  [TimeStepper]
    type = PostprocessorDT
    postprocessor = dt
    dt = 0.001
  []
[]

[Outputs]
  execute_on = 'timestep_end'
  file_base = mandel_fluid
  exodus = true
  [csv]
    interval = 3
    type = CSV
  []
[]

# Mandel's problem of consolodation of a drained medium - mechanics subapp

[Mesh]
  type = GeneratedMesh
  dim = 3
  nx = 10
  ny = 1
  nz = 1
  xmin = 0
  xmax = 1
  ymin = 0
  ymax = 0.1
  zmin = 0
  zmax = 1
[]

[GlobalParams]
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
  PorousFlowDictator = dictator
  block = 0
[]

[UserObjects]
  [dictator]
    type = PorousFlowDictator
    porous_flow_vars = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
    number_fluid_phases = 1
    number_fluid_components = 1
  []
  [pc]
    type = PorousFlowCapillaryPressureVG
    m = 0.8
    alpha = 1e-5
  []
[]

[Variables]
  [disp_x]
  []
  [disp_y]
  []
  [disp_z]
  []
[]

[BCs]
  [roller_xmin]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_x
    value = 0
    boundary = 'left'
  []
  [roller_ymin]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    value = 0
    boundary = 'bottom'
  []
  [plane_strain]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_z
    value = 0
    boundary = 'back front'
  []
  [top_velocity]
    type = FunctionDirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    function = top_velocity
    boundary = top
  []
[]

[Functions]
  [top_velocity]
    type = PiecewiseLinear
    x = '0 0.002 0.006   0.014   0.03    0.046   0.062   0.078   0.094   0.11    0.126   0.142   0.158   0.174   0.19 0.206 0.222 0.238 0.254 0.27 0.286 0.302 0.318 0.334 0.35 0.366 0.382 0.398 0.414 0.43 0.446 0.462 0.478 0.494 0.51 0.526 0.542 0.558 0.574 0.59 0.606 0.622 0.638 0.654 0.67 0.686 0.702'
    y = '-0.041824842    -0.042730269    -0.043412712    -0.04428867     -0.045509181    -0.04645965     -0.047268246 -0.047974749      -0.048597109     -0.0491467  -0.049632388     -0.050061697      -0.050441198     -0.050776675     -0.051073238      -0.0513354 -0.051567152      -0.051772022     -0.051953128 -0.052113227 -0.052254754 -0.052379865 -0.052490464 -0.052588233 -0.052674662 -0.052751065 -0.052818606 -0.052878312 -0.052931093 -0.052977751 -0.053018997 -0.053055459 -0.053087691 -0.053116185 -0.053141373 -0.05316364 -0.053183324 -0.053200724 -0.053216106 -0.053229704 -0.053241725 -0.053252351 -0.053261745 -0.053270049 -0.053277389 -0.053283879 -0.053289615'
  []
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [porepressure]
  []
  [stress_yy]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  []
  [tot_force]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  []
[]

[AuxKernels]
  [stress_yy]
    type = RankTwoAux
    rank_two_tensor = stress
    variable = stress_yy
    index_i = 1
    index_j = 1
  []
  [tot_force]
    type = ParsedAux
    args = 'stress_yy porepressure'
    execute_on = timestep_end
    variable = tot_force
    function = '-stress_yy+0.6*porepressure'
  []
[]

[Kernels]
  [grad_stress_x]
    type = StressDivergenceTensors
    variable = disp_x
    component = 0
  []
  [grad_stress_y]
    type = StressDivergenceTensors
    variable = disp_y
    component = 1
  []
  [grad_stress_z]
    type = StressDivergenceTensors
    variable = disp_z
    component = 2
  []
  [poro_x]
    type = PorousFlowEffectiveStressCoupling
    biot_coefficient = 0.6
    variable = disp_x
    component = 0
  []
  [poro_y]
    type = PorousFlowEffectiveStressCoupling
    biot_coefficient = 0.6
    variable = disp_y
    component = 1
  []
  [poro_z]
    type = PorousFlowEffectiveStressCoupling
    biot_coefficient = 0.6
    component = 2
    variable = disp_z
  []
[]

[Materials]
  [temperature]
    type = PorousFlowTemperature
  []
  [elasticity_tensor]
    type = ComputeElasticityTensor
    C_ijkl = '0.5 0.75'
    # bulk modulus is lambda + 2*mu/3 = 0.5 + 2*0.75/3 = 1
    fill_method = symmetric_isotropic
  []
  [strain]
    type = ComputeSmallStrain
  []
  [stress]
    type = ComputeLinearElasticStress
  []
  [eff_fluid_pressure]
    type = PorousFlowEffectiveFluidPressure
  []
  [ppss]
    type = PorousFlow1PhaseP
    porepressure = porepressure
    capillary_pressure = pc
  []
[]

[Postprocessors]
  [total_downwards_force]
     type = ElementAverageValue
     variable = tot_force
  []
  [dt]
    type = FunctionValuePostprocessor
    function = if(0.15*t<0.01,0.15*t,0.01)
  []
[]

[Preconditioning]
  [andy]
    type = SMP
    full = true
    petsc_options_iname = '-ksp_type -pc_type -sub_pc_type -snes_atol -snes_rtol -snes_max_it'
    petsc_options_value = 'gmres asm lu 1E-14 1E-10 10000'
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  solve_type = Newton
  start_time = 0
  end_time = 0.7
  [TimeStepper]
    type = PostprocessorDT
    postprocessor = dt
    dt = 0.001
  []
[]

[Outputs]
  execute_on = 'timestep_end'
[]
Thanks @cpgr

@WilkAndy - I don't think we have a loosely-coupled HM or THM example in the porous flow tests or examples? Did you want to work this up as a test/example @AhmedAlmetwally (as you raised it originally)?
yes, we do @WilkAndy  @cpgr
I'm kind of not keen to do this, as i've got other higher-priority things to look after.  But don't let me discourage you from doing it yourself !!!!!

node.title: PorousFlow - GW eq
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSE,
In think that the equations in the GW documentation miss the source/sink term. Obviously this is well implemented since a pumping test is simulated just bellow. So where are the sources/sink implemented?
Hope that my question makes sense.
Thanks again!!
Matias

There are so many different ways for implementing sources and sinks, depending on the particular physical situation.  For a start, look at https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/porous_flow/sinks.html and https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/porous_flow/boundaries.html

Hi Andy,
Thanks, I just wanted to know where are the sources added in the equations.
Another related question, the presentation 2 and 3 represent a HM coupled system?

Presentation 2 can be considered a coupled HM system, but note there's no physics prescribed to "espilon" - it's just assumed to appear from somewhere.  For a true HM system you'd have to add some TensorMechanics Kernels to calculate stresses, which would give the strain epsilon.
Presentation >=3 can kind-of be considered a coupled HM system.  "epsilon" is implicit inside the Biot Modulus or specific storage, and its only physics is associated with the very simple evolution captured by Eqn(7).  A solid mechanics person would scoff at this, but it's better than nothing, since it describes the impact of changing porepressure on the porosity of the rock matrix.

Ahhh that makes it pretty clear. Thanks for the great documentation, I also really like the figures.
Matias

node.title: Trouble installing moose - all tests fail
node.bodyText:
Our cluster recently went through an upgrade (I'm mentioning this in case something wonky happened that might be related to this). Anyways, I'm building MOOSE from scratch using https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/conda.html
Everything works perfectly/as expected until I execute "./run_tests -j 4" at which point all tests fail. The error given for basically all tests is FAILED (Application not found).
I followed the troubleshooting guide https://mooseframework.inl.gov/help/troubleshooting.html#failingtests. However, the "Application not found" issue does not seem to be the problem? Make works, and a valid moose_test-opt is present, which can be executed and run a sample problem. I performed all the debugging in the Build section (hello world, etc). Everything seems fine?
Need help understanding why all tests are failing and any suggestions how to fix it. Screen output is attached from the failed tests and debugging attempts...
moose_build_errors.txt

This is odd. I haven't seen this happen before, but I know that the logic to build or discover what the executable name should be can be fairly complex. It relies on various information from the platform, the directory structure and can be influenced by the "testroot" file too. There haven't been any changed merged to the TestHarness or testers in the last 2-3 months.
What I would suggest is that we attempt to printout what the TestHarness "thinks" the name of the binary should be and go from there. It appears that much of the logic for figuring out the app name occurs here. Adding a simple print statement after this block should do it:

  
    
      moose/python/TestHarness/TestHarness.py
    
    
        Lines 881 to 902
      in
      7aeadfc
    
  
  
    

        
          
           ## Save executable-under-test name to self.executable 
        

        
          
           exec_suffix = 'Windows' if platform.system() == 'Windows' else '' 
        

        
          
           self.executable = app_name + '-' + self.options.method + exec_suffix 
        

        
          
           # if the executable has a slash - assume it is a file path 
        

        
          
           if '/' in app_name: 
        

        
          
               self.executable = os.path.abspath(self.executable) 
        

        
          
           # look for executable in PATH - if not there, check other places. 
        

        
          
           elif shutil.which(self.executable) is None: 
        

        
          
               if os.path.exists(os.getcwd() + '/' + self.executable): 
        

        
          
                   # it's in the current working directory 
        

        
          
                   self.executable = os.getcwd() + '/' + self.executable 
        

        
          
               elif os.path.exists(os.path.join(self._rootdir, self.executable)): 
        

        
          
                   # it's in the testroot file's directory 
        

        
          
                   self.executable = self.executable 
        

        
          
                   # we may be hopping around between multiple (module) 
        

        
          
                   # subdirectories of tests - so the executable needs to be an 
        

        
          
                   # absolute path. 
        

        
          
                   self.executable = os.path.abspath(os.path.join(self._rootdir, self.executable)) 
        

        
          
               else: 
        

        
          
                   # it's (hopefully) in an installed location 
        

        
          
                   mydir = os.path.dirname(os.path.realpath(__file__)) 
        

        
          
                   self.executable = os.path.join(mydir, '../../../..', 'bin', self.executable) 
        
    
  


@aeslaughter or @milljm, any thoughts?

OK - I printed self.executable after line 902:
START DEBUG PRINT: TestHarness.py printing self.executable:
moose_test-opt
END DEBUG PRINT
Is there supposed to be a path in front of that?

Cody suggested running ./run_tests -j4 -v --dry-run to see if the executable path was correct. The running command includes an executable name without a full path - possibly the issue?
dirackernels/material_point_source.material_point_source_test: Working Directory: /beegfs1/home/eshemon/projects/moose/test/tests/dirackernels/material_point_sour                                                                                                                                     ce
dirackernels/material_point_source.material_point_source_test: Running command: moose_test-opt -i material_point_source.i --error --error-unused --error-override                                                                                                                                      --no-gdb-backtrace

Can you provide the results of your environment before running ./run_tests?:
env
I'd like a clear picture as to the environment the TestHarness is seeing.

Yes, sure. Here is the result of  env
env.txt

Well your PYTHON_PATH isn't set, that was another idea we had.
I'd like to continue to troubleshoot, but as a quick workaround you might just (temporarily) export the path to the binary you are trying to run. It's a hack but it should make all your tests pass.
export PATH=$PATH:/beegfs1/home/eshemon/projects/moose/test/
Thanks Cody, exporting the path definitely works as a quick workaround. Tests passing now.
Any update on why this issue was happening and a more permanent fix? I'm happy to debug online via remote call if that's easier.

Your PATH (was) is set to:
PATH=/home/eshemon/miniconda3/envs/moose/bin:/home/eshemon/miniconda3/condabin:.:/usr/local/bin:/usr/bin:/usr/local/sbin:/usr/sbin:/home/eshemon/bin
Can you remove the path to current working directory? :.: Basically make your path's value:
export PATH=/home/eshemon/miniconda3/envs/moose/bin:/home/eshemon/miniconda3/condabin:/usr/local/bin:/usr/bin:/usr/local/sbin:/usr/sbin:/home/eshemon/bin
Sometimes there exists aliases, symlinks, or some 'thing' in a current working directory which may end up finding stuff that we don't want. I realize people add a path like this so they don't have to invoke binaries with a prefixed ./, but the trouble this sometimes causes is not worth it. Not sure if this is your issue, but it's worth a shot.
I forgot to update this conversation, but I wanted to let you know that your suggestion worked. I removed the path to the current working directory and it fixed everything. Thanks for the help.
